fields.headline: For the record
fields.bodyText: "For rich tourists (like the PM) Padstow is an idyll, but for locals it's now a lost haven" (News, last week, page 19), claimed David Cameron and his family were staying with George Hollingbery, the Conservative MP for Meon Valley, Hampshire, during their Cornish holiday. They were actually renting from him. And the piece was incorrect when it said the MP owns three homes in the area: he owns two. "The man who stood on O'Connell bridge" (New Review, last week, pages 14-15), the illustrated story of Arthur Fields, the Dublin photographer, carried an incorrect caption. A 1950s image we said showed American film star Gene Tierney with an unknown man actually showed Movita (Marlon Brando's second wife) and the boxer/singer Jack Doyle. The headline "The fruit fly: our ancestors of 800 million years" (Discover, last week, page 22) was inaccurate. As the article explained, fruit flies are our very distant evolutionary cousins – the basic pattern of our bodies is dictated by the Hox genes we share. Those genes also patterned a common ancestor from 800 million years ago (actually not a fly but a very simple multicellular organism that lived in the sea). Write to Stephen Pritchard, Readers' Editor, the Observer, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU, tel 020 3353 4656 or email reader@observer.co.uk
